Description: On December 20, 2005, a Severity Level II Notice of Violation, with a proposed $96,000 Civil Penalty, was issued to the Pacific Gas and Electric Company as a result of the licensee's failure to: (1) keep adequate records of special nuclear material (SNM) inventory, transfer or disposal, (2) establish adequate procedures for control and accounting of SNM, and (3) conduct adequate physical inventories of SNM at the Humboldt Bay Power Plant (HBPP). PG&E's records failed to account for the whereabouts of three 18-inch fuel rod segments after they were cut from a single fuel rod in 1968. Likewise, PG&E's records failed to account for incore detectors after some were cut in 1973.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 926130: Regulation and Administration of Communications, Electric, Gas, and Other Utilities
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Pacific Gas and Electric Company was sentenced to submit to an expansive program of probation after having been found guilty of multiple willful violations of the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 and obstructing an agency proceeding. Among the provisions included in the program of probation were the obligation to submit to a corporate compliance and ethics monitorship, the obligation to complete 10,000 hours of community service, and the requirement to spend up to $3 million to inform the public in print advertisements and television commercials to notify the public of the utility's criminal and neglectful behavior.

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of San Francisco
Private Litigation Case Title: John Conley, et al. v.?Pacific Gas?and Electric Company

Description: The settlement called for PG&E to pay $5.5 million and the IBEW $500,000.
Private Litigation Case Title: Becky Greer et al v. Pacific Gas And Electric Company

Description: Pacific Gas and Electric Company agreed to pay $1 billion to resolve the wildfire claims brought by 18 local public entities (cities, counties, districts and public agencies) impacted by the 2015 Butte Fire, 2017 Northern California wildfires and 2018 Camp Fire.

PG&E agreed to pay $6.5 million to the City and County of San Francisco in settlement of allegations its neglect was responsible for a power outage in December 2003 caused by a fire at its Mission Street substation.

In Butte County Superior Court, PG&E agreed to plead guilty to more than 80 counts of manslaughter in connection with a 2018 forest fire blamed on the utility's faulty maintenance of transmission lines. The company agreed to pay a $3.5 million criminal fine and $500,000 in costs.
Settlement concerning the Power Fire and Whiskey Fire.
Info Source: U.S. SECURES $50.5M IN SETTLEMENTS FOR FIRES IN ELDORADO AND MENDOCINO NATIONAL FORESTS, US Fed News, June 6, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: Settlement concerning the Freds Fire and Sims Fire.
Info Source: US ATTORNEY'S OFFICE REACHES TWO SETTLEMENTS FOR $29.5M WITH PG&E REGARDING DAMAGE CAUSED BY 2 FOREST FIRES, US Fed News, March 15, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: air pollution violation
air pollution violation

PG&E agreed to pay project costs up to $190 million to for a project to clean the East Harbor and improve docks and waterfront facilities in settlement of allegations its former coal gasification plants near the harbor contaminated soils and sediments. Up to $29.4 million would be returned to the company through future marina revenues.
water pollution
Agency: California State Water Resources Control Board

Description: In an SEC filing, PG&E said it would pay a total of $565 million to settle multiple lawsuits stemming from a deadly 2010 natural gas pipeline explosion in San Bruno, California.

Pacific Gas and Electric Company agreed to a $5.9 million settlement to resolve alleged violations of PG&E's National Pollutant Discharge  Elimination System permit from discharges of once-through cooling water into the Pacific Ocean from its Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant.
Agency: California State Water Resources Control Board

Description: Following previous settlements of $333 million in 1996 and $295 million in 2006, PGE&E agreed to resolve additional claims relating to allegations that the utility was responsible for contaminating drinking water in Hinkley, California with the likely carcinogen chromium 6. These cases were made famous in the film "Erin Brockovich."

Following an initial settlement of $333 million in 1996, PGE&E agreed to resolve additional claims relating to allegations that the utility was responsible for contaminating drinking water in Hinkley, California with the likely carcinogen chromium 6. These cases were made famous in the film "Erin Brockovich."

The Commission approved a settlement between PG&E, CPSD, and the City and County of San Francisco (CCSF).  This proceeding was opened after investigative reports on the 2003 fire at PG&E's Mission Substation were issued.  The settlement requires PG&E shareholders to make payments totaling $6.5 million.

The California Public Utilities Commission ruled that Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) violated PUC billing rules and ordered the utility to refund approximately $35 million to consumers for unauthorized charges; to refund reconnection fees with interest; and to pay credits to certain customers whose service was shut off for nonpayment of illegal back-bills.

This decision fines PG&E $38,000,000 related to the natural gas explosion and fire that occurred on December 24, 2008  in Rancho Cordova, California, which resulted in one fatality, other injuries and property damage.

This decision approves a settlement between CPSD and PG&E regarding alleged violations of system resource adequacy requirements for March, April, and July 2010 and requires PG&E to make a $215,000 payment to the General Fund.
Notes: The source provides only the year, so the date is listed here as January 1.

Description: CPSD issued a citation to PG&E pursuant to Resolution ALJ-274 citing reported violations on several leak surveys not having been performed, in compliance with General Order 112-E, for certain pipeline facilities.

Decision approved settlement between CPSD and PG&E regarding alleged violations of mitigation measures set forth in Mitigation Monitoring Plan adopted in D.09-10-049 and required PG&E to make settlement payment of $100,000 to General Fund and a $50,000 donation to the Endangered Species Recovery Program at Stanislaus State Univ.

This decision approves a settlement between SED, PG&E and The Utility Reform Network concerning alleged improper activities on the part of PG&E employees regarding anti-smart meter groups. The settlement requires PG&E to pay $390,000 to the general fund of the State of California; carry through with improvements to the social media components of its employee policies and with education about those policies; sponsor three regulatory industry trainings, which a third-party will teach; and verify the completion of these things to SED by 2015.
Notes: The source provides only the year, so the date is listed here as January 1.

Description: The California Public Utilities Commission levied a $14.35 million fine against Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) for its failure to promptly notify the CPUC of incorrect records related to natural gas pipeline 147, which runs through the City of San Carlos.

The California Public Utilities Commission issued an order in response to Pacific Gas and Electric Company's September 15, 2014, disclosure of approximately 20 emails from January 2014 regarding the assignment of an Administrative Law Judge in PG&E's Gas Transmission and Storage rate case, in violation of the CPUC's Rules of Practice and Procedure. The order fined PG&E $1.05 million for ex parte violations.
Citation issued to PG&E for three violations
Citation issued to PG&E for two violations
Citation to PG&E for failure to set its pipeline relief valve within the allowable pressure limit
Citation to PG&E for lack of written quality control and quality assurance procedures to guide its personnel during normal operation and maintenance activities
Citation to PG&E for Safety Code Violation

The California Public Utilities Commission fined Pacific Gas and Electric Company $1.6 billion for the unsafe operation of its gas transmission system, including the pipeline rupture in San Bruno, Calif., in 2010. The decision ordered PG&E to pay $850 million in gas transmission pipeline safety infrastructure improvements; $300 million in a fine to the state's General Fund; $400 million in a one-time bill credit spread across PG&E's gas customers; and approximately $50 million towards other remedies to enhance pipeline safety.
Citation to PG&E for November 7, 2014, incident in San Jose
During demolition of an unused fuel oil tank by a PG&E subcontractor, a construction worker was injured and subsequently died of those injuries.
Citation to PG&E for August 26-27, 2014, incident at Metcalf Substation
Citation Issued to PG&E for Contractor Qualification Deficiencies

Pacific Gas and Electric Company failed to comply with applicable law and regulations in maintaining accurate records of its natural gas distribution system. These inaccurate records were relied on for locating and marking underground facilities in anticipation of excavation. They inaccurately mapped and consequently inaccurately marked facilities led to excavators damaging the distribution system in several instances. Release of natural gas, service interruptions and, in one case, significant property damage resulted.
Citation to PG&E for safety code violations
Citation to PG&E for Violation of General Order 95, Rule 35 and Resolution E-4184 for Butte Fire Ignited September 9, 2015
Citation to PG&E for Violation of General Order 95, Rule 31.1 for Butte Fire Ignited September 9, 2015
Citation to PG&E for October 18, 2015 Incident near Moss Landing Substation/Monterey
Citation to PG&E for safety code violations
Pacific Gas and Electric Co. agreed to pay $97.5 million in penalties for improper communication with regulators.
Citations totaling $5.05 million to PG&E for violations of regulations resulting from two separate incidents in 2016 and 2017

PG&E admittedly failed to timely report ex parte communications, and engaged in improper ex parte communications, in violation of Commission Rules of Practice and Procedure, as well as certain provisions of the Public Utilities Code.

An Administrative Law Judge increased to $110 million the proposed amount of penalties PG&E would pay to address the violations relating to its underground infrastructure. Of the total, $44 million was to go to the state's General Fund.
PG&E for failure to properly follow procedures that occurred on November 27, 2017 in San Francisco, Calif.

The California Public Utilities Commission imposed $1.937 billion in penalties against Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the largest penalty ever assessed by the CPUC, for the utility's role in the catastrophic 2017 and 2018 wildfires.
PG&E for failure to properly identify utility service lines which resulted in a natural gas incident that occurred on March 10, 2018 in San Jose, Calif.
Citation to PG&E for inadequate inspections of the Ignacio-Alto-Sausalito transmission lines from 2008-2019
Citation to PG&E for violating GO-165 related to the incomplete detailed inspection of 54,755 distribution poles in 2019

The California Public Utilities Commission approved penalties and permanent disallowances against Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) for violations related to the ignition of the 2019 Kincade wildfire. PG&E will pay a $40 million penalty to California's General Fund and incur an $85 million permanent disallowance for cost recovery for the removal of abandoned transmission facilities within its service territory, for a total of $125 million.
